The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles and qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles. Subsection (e) introduces the new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles and qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles. Subsection (e) introduces the new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle credit, determining the credit amount for a new hybrid flexible fuel motor vehicle placed in service during the taxable year. The credit amount for a vehicle based on city fuel economy ranges from $1,500 to $3,500, depending on the percentage increase compared to a comparable vehicle. The city fuel economy for determining a tax credit on a new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle is based on E-85 ethanol gallon equivalent for the vehicle and gasoline gallon equivalent for a comparable vehicle. The term 'new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle' refers to a qualified hybrid vehicle capable of running on alternative fuel, gasoline, or a blend of both. It must achieve a city fuel economy using E-85 ethanol that is at least 125% of a comparable nonhybrid vehicle fueled by gasoline. Subsection (d) does not apply to these vehicles. The extension of termination for new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles under section 30B of the Code is amended to December 31, 2014. This includes vehicles that achieve a city fuel economy using E-85 ethanol that is at least 125% of a comparable nonhybrid vehicle fueled by gasoline. Subsection (d) does not apply to these vehicles. The extension for new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles under section 30B of the Code is amended to December 31, 2014. Amendments include vehicles meeting specific fuel economy criteria and updates to subsections (i) and (k) of the Code. The extension for new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles under section 30B of the Code is amended to December 31, 2014. Amendments include updates to subsections (i) and (k) of the Code, changing references from subsections (e) to (f) and (g) to (h), and specifying exclusions for new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles. The amendments made to section 38 and section 1016(a) of the Code involve changing references from subsections (e) to (f) and (g) to (h), and specifying exclusions for new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles. These changes apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2006.
